hints_html:
The Maclaurin series for \(\cos x\) is

\(\cos x = 1 - \frac{x^{2}}{2!} + \frac{x^{4}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!}\)
hints_latex:
The Maclaurin series for $\cos x$ is

$\cos x = 1 - \frac{x^{2}}{2!} + \frac{x^{4}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!}$
hints_raw:
The Maclaurin series for <math> \cos x </math> is 

<math> \cos x = 1 - \frac{x^{2}}{2!} + \frac{x^{4}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!}</math>
question: 1 (j)
sols_html:
We apply \(t^{3}\) for ’x in the Maclaurin series for cos(x) to get

\(\cos (t^{3}) = 1 - \frac{t^{6}}{2!} + \frac{t^{12}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n}}{(2n)!}\)

Now we multiply by t to get

\(t\cos (t^{3}) = t - \frac{t^{7}}{2!} + \frac{t^{13}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+1}}{(2n)!}\)

Now we integrate to get

\(\int t\cos (t^{3}) = C + \frac{t^{2}}{2} - \frac{t^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{t^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}\)

Applying the endpoints gives

\(\int_{0}^{x} t\cos (t^{3}) = \frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}\)

and so the first three nonzero terms are

\(\frac{x^{2}}{2}, - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!}, \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!}\)

completing the question.
sols_latex:
We apply $t^{3}$ for \emph{'x} in the Maclaurin series for \emph{cos(x)}
to get

$\cos (t^{3}) = 1 - \frac{t^{6}}{2!} + \frac{t^{12}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n}}{(2n)!}$

Now we multiply by \emph{t} to get

$t\cos (t^{3}) = t - \frac{t^{7}}{2!} + \frac{t^{13}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+1}}{(2n)!}$

Now we integrate to get

$\int t\cos (t^{3}) = C + \frac{t^{2}}{2} - \frac{t^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{t^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}$

Applying the endpoints gives

$\int_{0}^{x} t\cos (t^{3}) = \frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}$

and so the first three nonzero terms are

$\frac{x^{2}}{2}, - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!}, \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!}$

completing the question.
sols_raw:
We apply <math> t^{3} </math> for '''x'' in the Maclaurin series for ''cos(x)'' to get

<math> \cos (t^{3}) = 1 - \frac{t^{6}}{2!} + \frac{t^{12}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n}}{(2n)!}</math>

Now we multiply by ''t'' to get

<math> t\cos (t^{3}) = t - \frac{t^{7}}{2!} + \frac{t^{13}}{4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+1}}{(2n)!}</math>

Now we integrate to get

<math> \int t\cos (t^{3}) = C + \frac{t^{2}}{2} - \frac{t^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{t^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{t^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}</math>

Applying the endpoints gives

<math> \int_{0}^{x} t\cos (t^{3}) = \frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!} + \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!} - ... = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \frac{x^{6n+2}}{(6n+2)(2n)!}</math>

and so the first three nonzero terms are

<math>
\frac{x^{2}}{2}, - \frac{x^{8}}{8\cdot2!}, \frac{x^{14}}{14\cdot 4!}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html: Find the first three nonzero terms in the power series representation in powers of x (i.e. the Maclaurin series) for \(\int_{0}^{x} t\cos(t^{3})\, dt\).
statement_latex:
Find the first three nonzero terms in the power series representation in
powers of \emph{x} (i.e. the Maclaurin series) for
$\int_{0}^{x} t\cos(t^{3})\, dt$.
statement_raw: Find the first three nonzero terms in the power series representation in powers of ''x'' (i.e. the Maclaurin series) for <math> \int_{0}^{x} t\cos(t^{3})\, dt </math>.
